thread.title: FBI recovers artwork stolen by Nazis in WWII
thread.title_full: FBI recovers artwork stolen by Nazis in WWII

author: Anne Barker
title: FBI recovers artwork stolen by Nazis in WWII
text:
Map: Germany 
FBI agents have recovered a 17th century oil painting that disappeared more than 80 years ago. 
Young Man as Bacchus was one of hundreds of works confiscated by the Nazis from a German art dealer before World War II. 
And though its original owner is long dead, his lost collection is slowly being tracked down around the world. 
Max Stern was the son of a German Jewish art collector who set up the famous Gallery Stern in Dusseldorf before World War I. 
When his father died in 1934, Dr Stern took ownership of the gallery, but two years later the Nazis forced him and other Jewish people to hand over their art and other assets. 
Young Man as Bacchus, an oil painting by the Dutch master Jan Franse Verzijl, was one of the 400 artworks Dr Stern lost. Who was Max Stern? Dr Stern fled Germany in 1937 and was interred as an enemy alien in a refugee camp on the British Isle of Man Two years later the British government allowed him to immigrate to Canada Dr Stern is remembered as an icon in the art community and gave generously to museums across Canada 
Maria Vullo heads a small investigative team in New York called the Holocaust Claims Processing Office that tracks down art and other assets stolen by the Nazis. 
"Dr Stern was a victim of legalized persecution in his native Germany due to his religion," she said. 
"That caused him to become, in turn, a refugee, 'an enemy alien', 'a civilian alien', and finally in his new home in Montreal a successful and influential art dealer." 
Ms Vullo said Dr Stern took measures to ensure his art might be recovered one day. 
"Although Dr Stern did not live to see the return of his art, he had hope for the future. 
"He bequeathed his assets including his interest in recovered art work to three non-profit institutions of higher learning, hoping for days like today when restitution would happen." Many stolen artworks never recovered 
It has taken years, if not decades, of painstaking investigation for the artwork to be returned. 
The art world is notoriously secretive, and so much art is hidden away on the walls of people who might know nothing about its provenance. Photo: Dr Clarence Epstein, director of the Max Stern Art Restitution Project, inspects the back of Young Man as Bacchus. (AP: Mary Altaffer) 
One day the investigators discovered and confirmed the painting was in New York, and they alerted the FBI, whose agents, including Michael McGarrity, moved in. 
"The painting has wandered the globe for nearly 80 years since being forced into sale under the auspices of the Nazi regime," Mr McGarrity said. 
"Young Man as Bacchus was most recently owned by the Luigi Caretto Gallery in Turin, Italy. 
"The gallery, with no knowledge of the painting's unfortunate past, had consigned it for sale at an art fair in New York City recently, in 2015. 
"The FBI seized the painting after being made aware of its existence at the fair and today we return it to the rightful owners, the Stern Foundation." 
The Dutch masterpiece is the 16th of Dr Stern's German artworks that investigators have managed to track down. 
At an official ceremony at New York's Museum of Jewish Heritage, Museum's CEO Michael Glickman handed the artwork over to representatives of the Stern Foundation. 
"Today is yet another example of an opportunity to provide justice to the memory of Dr Max Stern, who managed Gallery Stern in Dusseldorf, Germany," Mr Glickman said. 
"From the most unjust of times, a measure of justice is restored today." 
Of Dr Stern's 400 lost works, hundreds are still missing and may never be found. 
But investigators said the recovery of Young Man as Bacchus was a small symbol of justice to those who suffered the unspeakable horrors of the Holocaust.
